unittitle.value: Papers of Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The collection includes correspondence, orders, memoranda, petitions, indentures, and writings on military topics by Baron von Steuben during his tenure as an officer of the American army, as well as material relating to his estate and memorials.

p.value: Researchers on site may print out unlimited copies from microfilm reader-printer machines at per-exposure rates. See guidelines in Reading Room for details.
This collection should be cited as the Steuben Papers, MS 591, The New-York Historical Society.

Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben (1730-1794) served as inspector general of the Continental army and is credited with introducing to it European military concepts that began its transformation into a truly professional military establishment.
The volume "The Exercise of Troops" (in French), undated but bound within covers that are pages of a 1778 newspaper, has not been microfilmed.
